awd_titl_txt: UNS:  Mechanisms of Surface Charging in Nonpolar Media
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET - 1511619
PI: Schneider, James

Many products of technological importance involve suspensions of particles in liquids.  This project examines the mechanisms of electrical charge formation on particles immersed in nonpolar liquids.  The formation of charges on particles can create electrostatic repulsions between the particles that inhibit their aggregation, which leads to a stable suspension.  Certain types of surfactants can be added to the suspension as charging agents to help stabilize the suspension electrostatically.  The PI has developed a method to synthesize collections of surfactants with systematic variations in their molecular structures.  The surface charging characteristics of these surfactants will be characterized by using two instruments developed by the co-PIs.  Results of the project will help test theories of charging in nonpolar media and ultimately lead to the rational design of improved surfactant materials for charging and particle stabilization in nonpolars. Such systems are important in a variety of technologies, including e-readers, oil-based toners for printing, and slow-release fertilizers.  The researchers will use the example of the e-reader to engage K-12 students in the basic science underlying display technology and will develop a module for use in university student instruction.

This project aims to resolve long-standing questions concerning charge formation in nonpolar solvents by creating libraries of high-purity, custom-synthesized surfactants and studying their propensity to stabilize particles. The synthesis technique gives full control of tail length, extent of branching, headgroup chemistry, and counterion composition. Surface charging will be measured on test surfaces of controlled chemistry using the ZetaSpin method, which makes zeta potential measurements without concern for particle flocculation during the measurement. Inter-particle potentials will be measured by the highly sensitive TIRM method.  Elucidation of interparticle potentials will determine if the Gouy-Chapman theory or the counterion-only theory is a valid descriptor of charge screening effects in different systems. The corresponding decay lengths will give a more reliable measure of ionic strength than can be obtained from conductivity measurements. This project will provide valuable insight into the rational design of charging compounds and will help develop new theories to describe inter-particle potentials in doped nonpolars.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to study how surfactants form micelles and adsorb to surfaces in nonpolar liquids, such as corn oil, mineral oil, or other petroleum products. Such understanding is vital for the design of new surfactants that can be used to stabilize dispersions in oils for agricultural treatments and food products; increase the conductivity of oils for power storage applications and safe transport of oils; and to discover new oil-based, self-assembled micelle structures that can be used in a wide variety of applications from chemical synthesis to drug delivery.

The intellectual merit of the project centered on: (1) the development of new classes of surfactants that form micelles in oils and whose structures can be precisely controlled; and (2) the development of novel colloidal instrumentation that can be used to study self-assembly and adsorption phenomena in these low-conductivity materials.

We first synthesized a group of surfactants with similar structure to Aerosol OT, making changes to their tail length and degree of branching. We found that tail branching was a requirement for oil solubility in most cases. We made changes to the ionizable headgroup to vary counterion binding strength for later studies. Most of these surfactants did form micelles, and those that did not were unable to significantly increase conductivity in oils. This suggests that micelle formation is required for substantial ion formation in oils.

We developed two important tools for the characterization of self-assembly and adsorption in oils. The first, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), was used for many years to study charge transport in nonpolar liquids. For this project, we needed to measure the concentration of charge carriers (not merely the conductivity) so that they could be identified as micelles vs. surfactant monomers, for example. A main complication was that the surfactant material tended to adsorb to the EIS electrodes, and this layer of material obscured signals desired for bulk ion transport and transport in the electrical double layer. We overcame this obstacle by coating the electrodes with a nanoscale fluoropolymer film and used the EIS instrument to size charge carriers for the surfactants we synthesized and others of interest to the field. Several other key theoretical advances were made in EIS modeling, including the construction of a “universal curve” that can be used to check for proper installation of sample and choice of electrode gap. Using the EIS, we found that tightly bound counterions gave lower charge carrier concentration compared with looser-bound organic counterions, with the tighter-binding versions giving about the same charge density as nonionizable surfactants.

Of particular concern in the study of surfactant adsorption to particles in oils is making confident measurements of the particle’s surface charge by their motion in electric fields. While these measurements are routine in water-based systems, some complicating effects arise in oils. In most cases, one observes a field-dependent electrophoretic mobility that prevents ready interpretation of the mobility data. There is a strong tendency for many particles of interest to aggregate in oils, preventing a mobility measurement. Finally, at low conductivity the governing theories are uncertain without prior knowledge of the Debye screening length and its comparison to particle curvature. In the project, we used a rotating disk method (ZetaSpinTM) to measure surface charge through the observed potential of a flat plate spinning in an oil mixture of interest. While ZetaSpinTM was previously developed in water-based systems, transferring the technique to oils presented several challenges. One was that the electrodes and other device components had to be reconfigured for compatibility with oil. Another is that the currents generated by spinning a charged surface in oil were very small and new, more sensitive metering was required. Once these were addressed, we used the ZetaSpinTM method to interrogate surface charging on mica, silica, and other surfaces using the surfactants synthesized above and others of interest to the field. We also studied the impact of water on the surface charge of these materials in surfactant-laden oil and found a slow but repeatable surface charging process that we believe is mediated by the transport of water droplets to the surface via surfactant micelles.

Broader impacts of the project include the training of 1 Ph.D student, 4 M.S. students, and 5 undergraduate researchers. One of the undergraduate researchers is an NSF GRF recipient. Both the nonpolar EIS system and the nonpolar ZetaSpinTM system are housed in the Carnegie Mellon CPS Lab and are available for research and teaching use. A lab using the ZetaSpinTM method has been developed for undergraduate and graduate coursework.
